qas.question: This species relies on other species to provide a reproductive host for their offspring.
It is believed that parasitoids account for what percentage of the total insect population?
During a parasitoid-host interaction what will happen to the host?
What is the term given to organisms living and feeding on their host?
How many organisms in the insect species are Diptera or Cleoptera parasitoids?
Which type of wasp is a well-known example of a parasitoid?
How do the larvae of the parasitoid wasps kill their prey?

answers.text: devouring the internal organs until finally destroying the nervous system

plausible_answers.text: living in or on their host and feeding directly upon it

qas.question: How do caterpillars feed during the day?
What does a caterpillar living on an organism do to the organism?
What kind of relationship to caterpillars have with their host?

plausible_answers.text: do not kill their hosts instantly

qas.question: How do caterpillars harm their hosts?
What percent of insect species are catepillars?

context: <a3_0>Parasitoids<a3_0/> are organisms <b7_0>living in or on their host and feeding directly upon it<b7_0/>, <b8_0>eventually leading to its <a2_0>death<b8_0/><a2_0/>. They are much like parasites in their <b9_0>close symbiotic<b9_0/> relationship with their host or hosts. Like the previous two classifications parasitoid predators <b10_0>do not kill their hosts instantly<b10_0/>. However, unlike parasites, they are very similar to true predators in that the fate of their prey is quite inevitably death. A well-known example of a parasitoids are the <a0_0><a5_0>ichneumon<a5_0/> wasps<a0_0/>, solitary insects living a free life as an adult, then laying eggs on or in another species such as a caterpillar. Its larva(e) feed on the growing host causing it little harm at first, but soon <a6_0>devouring the internal organs until finally destroying the nervous system<a6_0/> resulting in prey death. By this stage the young wasp(s) are developed sufficiently to move to the next stage in their life cycle. Though limited mainly to the insect order Hymenoptera, Diptera and Coleoptera parasitoids make up <b11_0>as much as <a1_0><a4_0>10%<b11_0/><a4_0/><a1_0/> of all insect species.
